I'm also excited to see how the media will kvetch over our mere existence; never in a millions years would I've thought that I'd be part of something that generated this amount of assblasting worldwide.

>>516c8312-9c2d-4f0f-9755-7b62503dd0a1
8chan is going to be even more of a husk than what it was originally. I would say that we should completely abandon it and pursue decentralization, but the problem is that that's exactly what (((they))) want; they want to quarantine us from the internet so that our viewpoints don't seep into the mainstream. 

Maybe decentralized internet will be the next big thing, but it currently isn't, so we need to have a presence on Internet 1.0 if we still want to educate the masses. Yeah, we'll get banned, but a lot of other people are getting banned too and are waking up to the bullshit of a wholly centralized and consolidated internet owned by 1 or 2 companies. It's why alternatives like Minds for social media are on the rise. The need and desire to change are certainly there; these people just need to be told where to go.

Gone are the days of comfyposting during a happening. One wonders how often the "state of emergency" will be spammed to stifle conversation. **It's dead, Jim**

The testimony I pulled this from is a 6 page pdf which features 10 answers to points raised by the subpoena; everything else is rather benign and can be summed up by "8chan is a 1st Amendment imageboard", "8chan dindu nuffin", and "8chan will bend over backwards and take it up the ass for law enforcement in the future".

Are there alternative clearnet platforms to spread these memes to? **Ones that don't need a mobile phone number to register are preferable so I can make a couple of "signal-pushing" accounts like I did with Twitter before they were all banned.**

>>dc16d74e-4981-4a06-8b19-fd965624e443
>How can we encourage and economically support more right wing culture?
Encouraging such endeavors requires them to be seen as economically viable by content creators, else it is only going to be pursued by passionate hobbyists, rather than a wider pool of workers as a full-time job. There are two large problems that need to be addressed to this end: First, is being able to secure some platform or means of economically paying creators for whatever they do. Given today's political pressure from "soft" (i.e. corporations) and "hard" (i.e. governments) bodies, anything associated with banks, credit card companies, or intermediaries, like Paypal, are out. This leaves cryptocurrency as the only feasible option, given its p2p nature of handling transactions; no governments or banks needed, therefore no one to separate the content creators from their earnings. The downsides at the moment are the market volatility of many cryptocurrencies and the new nature of the technology; namely, the fact that people have a reasonable understanding of how fiat currencies and banks work, but less so of cryptocurrencies and blockchains, which ultimately means they will be more wary of adopting the technology. Perhaps this will change with newer generations as these ideas trickle down and begin getting taught at schools.

The second main problem is securing a platform to sell or advertise the product or company. Speaking mainly from a digital perspective, this requires the use of ''alternative'' social media and video hosting; though places like Twitter, Facebook, Youtube, and Reddit reach an enormous number of people, they are quick to censor wrongthink ("soft" political pressure). Supporting, or even taking ownership (via mass immigration of politically like-minded users), of places like Bitchute, Minds, and so forth, would attain this end, with the upside that it would also secure a means of distributing memes, information, and redpills into the clearnet and the places we have been forbidden to post our ideas on. 

Basically, we need decentralized payments to circumvent a third party from economically choking white companies, and a mixture of decentralized and clearnet advertising/distribution platforms; the former to similarly prevent censorship, and the latter to attract more people into the white economy.

>inb4 2020 Election to make Trump look bad.
That would make sense if Trump wasn't Zion Don. I'm not convinced of an incoming market crash because there are some people who are making too much money out of it; why crash a system that works for them?

Playing singleplayer is agony.

>>d3b17353-f50e-4e77-87af-794debeccc5a

>>e9991204-da08-4125-bd4e-5d2dc7ccf979
>Also her Date a Live artbook is being re-released, if you're into it and you happen to live in nipland in this case I have a favor to ask
Currently living here. Do you have an Amazon link or something? Maybe I can procure it and pass on scans.

>>074a7ebc-9d1b-44f8-8037-c4c5f7126564
The offer is there **provided the stuff you want to buy is not that expensive or degenerate. Anons have to stick together during these dark times.**

In regards to your plans, **the voice SIM that people on a tourist visa are allowed to buy doesn't have a working cell number - only gaijins on a long-term (> 3 months) can apply - so you're right in thinking that it won't work. Another potential issue is that some of these websites will only accept credit/debit cards issued in Japan (some don't even accept Paypal; Melonbooks is an example, which is why you have tons of middle-men companies that "purchase" the stuff you want on your behalf and then send it to you for an additional handling fee). Provided you can purchase the item, for outlets that have an agreement with a konbini (i.e. Amazon), pick-up is easy: Typically, you receive an email with some code numbers which you enter at one of the touch-screen kiosks. Then, a receipt is printed out which you present to the counter in exchange for your package; only thing that may be required is ID. However, I largely suspect the process is only easy because it is assumed that the person picking up the package is a long-term resident of Japan, though I might be wrong.**

Feel free to ask more questions; I've been here for a couple of months, however, my nip progress is almost non-existent. This language is fucking hard, man; I can't remember this shit after working a long day. You can actually live in Japan without knowing a word of Japanese.

>>1c4264a5-2bbf-4300-ba74-f875c4f9a50c
**You ''can'' receive calls on a voice SIM, however they are taken through a VoIP number, which banks/stores/etc. in Japan don't take as a "real" number because it isn't permanent. An old telecom's law demands permanent numbers can only be doled out to long term residents. Maybe you could just use the number of the place you are staying, because all correspondence typically goes through email anyway.**
**Looking at the payment section of the website (see section お支払い here: https://www.melonbooks.co.jp/clipboard/) it appears you might also be able pay at a convenience store or "post-pay" when you pick your package up; a back-up for if your credit card doesn't get accepted. "Post-pay" is a similar process to picking up a package as I reiterated in my previous post, except you settle the amount at the convenience store rather than online.**
**Depends on your definition of "die"; if you mean being faced with postal workers who probably won't speak a word of English, then likely. However, they should be able to figure out what you want if you present your ID and say 「パッケージを集めます。」 - "pakkeji wo atsumemasu" - "I'm collecting a package". We do the things we do because we are passionate men.**

The lady is right; kanji is fucking impossible.

>>98f9aef1-950c-465d-9038-6e1c5c163093
**At that stage, it's not so much about whether you're a long-term resident or not, it's more about whether you're the actual person whom the package is intended, so any form of ID should be fine. Queue times will depend on where you are; a post office in the middle of Tokyo might be hell, but those out in the suburbs aren't too bad, provided you don't visit at their busiest hours (i.e. lunch time or when people get off work ~1700-1800).**

In any case, good luck and Godspeed, anon.

>>6d9a8b5a-fdf2-4786-9b89-ec8e792a24d9
>So is 8chan dead or like what?
Yes and yes. First because you can't access the website and second because of new "reforms" Mr. Pig-Farmer had to implement because of pressure from the congressional panel, see >>cfbf6afc-b832-4494-bc45-ca9604bdfc12. I think some anons bit the bullet and went to 4chan or Mark's bunker of faggotry, while others just disappeared into the ether. The traffic of this place is glacial because of low numbers, and I don't think it is going to get any better because some anons think this is a honeypot.

You have to git gud and **lightly, so that the darkened area is still in view, jerk the image up and down, either by scrolling or clicking and dragging. I've found that you don't really need to full-screen it to see the effect. Alternatively, if you can get it on a phone screen, just shaking the phone will give you the same effect.**

Try another one, anon.

Edit: Tor browser seems to have really slow scrolling, so I'd recommend saving it on your computer or trying another browser.

>>23205214-b278-4c73-a279-571126c56cf4

I'm almost certain this will be Kojima's final transformation into the film director he always wanted to be; it'll be more movie than game with cutscenes or quick time events replacing gameplay. Hell, Sony's already been doing down that road for a while now.

>>dd469e1c-bd86-4673-b294-8e3ac36ab130
I don't even know if I want to look at the website when it comes back online; it is going to be so fucking neutered it won't even be funny. It's like watching your hometown being infested with niggers; you feel some connection because it's where you grew up and had fun, but now it only brings sadness as you realize how it has turned into a complete shithole.

>>5dda141d-5cbd-4630-af2f-ca93f9e90b2b
>I just want to talk about video games goddamnit, I am not a fucking revolutionary plotting to overthrow our oligarchy
Too bad, anon. It's because you're wanting to talk about video games your way that made you a revolutionary in (((their))) eyes; you can't escape the rabbit-hole you've fallen down.

>>a0241372-a7d8-4c0f-8860-f8d0afd6a858
I don't remember the /nep/ general having that high a pph even when 8chan was in its prime; it's a combination of that plus how slow 08chan is that gives you the impression that it's dead. It'll get better: Just remember that the real anonymous imageboard will forever live in your heart.

posts.subject: Cakekike named in Halle Manifesto
posts.body:
==Looks like Mark has taken care of it again==

>A gunman has killed two people in eastern Germany after attempting to enter a synagogue where dozens were observing a Jewish holiday. The suspect broadcast the attack on a popular live-streaming platform before being arrested.

From his manifesto:
>"There is one person I want to thank especially. That’s Mark, former BO of 8ch /v/ and owner of vch.moe. His gracious donation of 0,1 bitcoin helped me a lot. He should be really pissed right now, of course. I wanted to kill only mudslimes and promised, I wouldn’t name him. You know what?
>Fuck you, you filthy jew.
>If this person even exist in RL. He could be a CIAnigger trying to radicalize and set up people online, for all that I know. I mean, why would a fucking jew give away money for free?"

Grab the stream capture (about 1GB) before it's gone:
https://anonfile.com/b4X0b485n2/492207255_mp4
https://mega.nz/#!QGJjmAZB!9PNVtCaAkpac3_7-Qa1BKioZx8iXVHwQUBdxXyuDJPA
And here are the three manifestos circulating, including a page of unlockable achievements. **Convenient false flag just as 8ch was coming back online? Or someone who's just had enough?**

>>f5a61084-793b-4652-b8e0-9533aa5b8c10
You better believe it, anon, and cripplekike along with other forces are doing everything they can to make it stay that way.

>>2dc648d9-990a-4fa7-8460-f88281b30808
>Will 8chan ever come back?
Given Cripplekike's current crusade against it, probably not for a while. Even then, it's probably going to be even more of a honeypot than before and flooded with shills like you wouldn't believe.

>Where did all the anons go?
No clue, probably 4chan, but who would want to go back there? I wish I knew where everyone went, because I feel really disconnected, not only from happenings and stupid political shit, but socially too. Talking with people online or offline, it's obvious to me that I will never have anything in common with these fucking normalfags. **You guys are the only ones who understand me**
